taxonomicNotes: Marceniuk (2005) placed this species in Aspistor, but it is now generally agreed that the appropriate name is Sciades parkeri. A revised (unified) nomenclature for Ariidae is currently underway (R. Betancur pers. comm. 2014).

Records of eastern Atlantic Myliobatis aquila from southern Brazil probably refer to this species, if both species are indeed distinct (if not, the name M. aquila has priority). There are two sister species in the southern part of its range under the present name M. goodei, with a description of the second species pending (Ruocco et al. 2012).
Last et al. (2016a) revised the genus Rhinobatos, transferring glaucostigma, horkelii, lentiginosus, leucorhynchus, percellens, planiceps, prahli, and productus to the new genus Pseudobatos.

Acanthopagrus vagus was previously confused with A. berda (Forsskål 1775) in South Africa (Heemstra and Heemstra 2004). This species was recently separated as a separate species from A. berda (Iwatsuki and Heemstra 2010).

This may be a subpopulation of Acanthopagrus schlegelli (Y. Iwatsuki pers. comm. 2009). Mitochondrial DNA analyses based on cytochrome b gene sequences did not distinguish individuals of A. schlegelii and A. sivicolus, reflecting either historical introgression or recent speciation and incomplete sorting of their mitochondrial lineages (Hsu et al. 2011). Pending further taxonomic work, A. sivicolus is here regarded as a distinct species.

Genetic analysis of the geographical partitioning revealed that this species showed an Atlantic-Mediterranean partitioning (Patarnello et al. 2007) indicating that exchanges between subpopulations are reduced and may limit rescue effects from migration and dispersal from other subpopulations to compensate for impacts of direct exploitation.

Acanthurus chronixis is a close relative of Acanthurus pyroferus, sharing the count of VIII dorsal spines and the same morphology, in particular the protruding snout (Randall 2001a).  Its taxonomic status is uncertain due to limited number of specimens. There is taxonomic work underway to determine the status of this species. We accept current taxonomy that this species is valid (Eschmeyer 2011, J.E. Randall pers comm. 2011).

Much of the literature recognizes the genus Elacatinus with two subgenera: Elacatinus and Tigrigobius. As such, this species is often referred to in the literature as Elacatinus redimiculus (Taylor and Akins 2007).
This species is easily confused with Coryphopterus glaucofraenum and C. venezuelae.

This species is often confused with C. glaucofraenum and C. tortugae. Although genetically distinct, C. glaucofraenum and C. venezuelae are extremely similar (Baldwin et al. 2009). There are some unresolved taxonomic issues surrounding the synonimization of Coryphopterus bol (described from Puerto Rico in 2008) under C. venezuelae (Collette and Smith-Vaniz 2013).
This species is easily confused with Coryphopterus hyalinus. Coryphopterus hyalinus and C. personatus are genetically distinct (Baldwin et al. 2009).
Older records of Coryphopterus in the western Atlantic may need to be verified as the genus has recently been revised (Baldwin et al. 2009).
The genus Canthigaster is hypothesized to undergo fast morphological/color differentiation and slow mtDNA evolution (Randall et al. 2008).

Species of the genus Arothron have been distinguished primarily on the basis of their distinctive colour patterns due to morphological similarities between species, however it is important to note that many species are highly polychromatic (Su and Tyler 1986).

The nomenclature of the bonefish family Albulidae is currently in a state of revision. Until recently, bonefish were considered to be comprised of two species, the circumglobal Albula vulpes and the western Atlantic and eastern Pacific Albula nemoptera; however, new molecular genetic information indicates that there are at least eight morphologically indistinguishable, but genetically distinct species (Colborn et al. 2001). Wallace and Tringali (2010) have recently found nine distinct species. The few treatments of fisheries in this region are assumed to be A. glossodonta. Albula glossodonta has been found to be the sister species of A. vulpes (Bowen et al. 2008).  Pacific and Indian Ocean populations are distinct (Colborn et al. 2001). Friedlander et al. (2008) found genetic differences between populations in the Line Islands and Hawaii.
Further study is required for the genus Stenogobius.
This is the only species in the family Cheimarrichthyidae worldwide (McDowall 2000).
Formerly placed in genus Pomolobus (Lee et al. 1980).
The placement of this species in the genus Acentrogobius requires confirmation (H.K. Larson pers. comm. 2019).
The name Cynoglossus semifasciatus has been wrongly applied to the commercial species on the Malabar coast, namely, C. macrostomus (Menon 1971, 1977).

A study using allozymes as a genetic marker (Eitner 1995) indicated that an unrecognized fourth species of Alopias may exist, however this claim was based on data from a single shark specimen likely to have been A. vulpinus. Recent work investigating population structure of all three Alopias species using mitochondrial DNA control region sequences (Trejo 2005) has found no evidence indicating that a fourth species of thresher sharks exists.

This species is sometimes confused with Rhinoptera bonasus, which can only be distinguished by counting the series of toothplates. Rhinoptera bonasus usually have seven series of plates in both jaws, while R. brasiliensis teeth are typically arranged in series of nine (Last et al. 2016).
The specific name has been misspelled and consistently used in the literature as Rhizoprionodon lalandei, but the original spelling R. lalandii should be retained.

This species is sometimes confused with Rhinoptera brasiliensis, which can only be distinguished from R. bonasus by counting the series of toothplates. Rhinoptera bonasus usually have seven series of plates in both jaws, while R. brasiliensis teeth are typically arranged in series of nine (Last et al. 2016).

Nurse sharks occurring in the eastern Pacific were formerly considered part of this species concept, however the Pacific Nurse Shark (Ginglymostoma unami) has now been formally described as a separate species (Del Moral-Flores et al. 2015).
Molecular studies are required to determine the level of genetic distinctness between the species in the Southwest Atlantic and the Southeast Pacific.

Bathytoshia formerly was a junior synonym of Dasyatis, which is now recognised as a valid species (Last et al. 2016); hence Dasyatis (Bathytoshia) centroura is now Bathytoshia centroura. This western Atlantic species is not conspecific with Bathytoshia of the eastern Atlantic (Last et al. 2016); the eastern Atlantic population that was formerly included within Dasyatis centroura is now included within B. lata (Last et al. 2016). The status of the single record from India is unknown.

authority: Pouyaud, Wirjoatmodjo, Rachmatika, Tjakrawidjaja, Hadiaty & Hadie, 1999
taxonomicNotes: This species is nearly identical in appearance to Latimeria chalumnae from the western Indian Ocean.

There are no specimens known from any collection. The seven type specimens are missing. This species was collected from four cave systems in Santa Cruz Island in the 1960s. It is currently known from photographs and observations in the wild from the 1990s.
Miller and Stefanni (2001) recognized a different subspecies at each of its three known localities: Bathygobius lineatus arundelii, B. l. lineatus and B. l. lupinus, respectively.

Blue Marlin (Makaira nigricans) of the Indo-Pacific and the Atlantic are conspecific (Buonaccorsi et al. 1999, 2001; Collette et al. 2006). The Indo-Pacific Blue Marlin previously was known as Makaira mazara (Jordan and Snyder).

This species was previously known as Tetrapturus albidus (Collette et al. 2006). There is a question as to whether this species is distinct from the Pacific Striped Marlin, Kajikia audax (Graves 1998, Collette et al. 2006, Hanner et al. 2011).
This species was previously referred to as Pleuronectes ferrugineus, then Limanda ferruginea, and is now placed in the genus Myzopsetta (Vinnikov et al. 2018).
This species is also spelled as Chriolepis lepidotus.
This species is possibly conspecific with Halichoeres malpelo from Malpelo Island. Genetic studies should be undertaken.
This species is closely related to ,i>Thalassoma purpureum in the Indo-Pacific region (Bernardi et al. 2004).
Possibly conspecific with Halichoeres salmofasciatus from Cocos Island. Genetic studies are needed.
Also known as Arcos poecilophthalmos.

This species is at the single location where it is known. It is intermediate in character between two abundant species (Myripristis benrndti and M. clarionensis) at the same location, therefore it may possibly be a hybrid.
This species is also known as Chriolepis walkerii (Findley 1983).
Lin and Hastings (2013) reallocated Labrisomus dendriticus to the genus Gobioclinus.
This species is closely related to Pseudochromis punctatus Kotthaus, 1970 (Randall 1995).

This species has in the past been commonly confused with and previously referred to as C. aygula in Australian waters (Randall and Kuiter 1982). It was also referred to as C. cyaena by Whitley (1937) and others.
For taxonomic treatment see Allen (1983).
For taxonomic treatment see Gomon (2006).

There have been problems arising from earlier records of distribution and management of this species in southern Australia due to confusion with A. viridis up until 30 years ago. Earlier records of large size of A. viridis in South Australia (Scott et al. 1974) refer to A. gouldii as does management aspects of Achoerodus in the Spencer Gulf (J.H. Choat pers. comm.. 2008).

Fernholm treats the genus Paramyxine Dean, 1908 as a synonym of Eptatretus Cloquet 1819 (Fernholm 1998, Fernholm and Quattrini 2008), while other authors treat Paramyxine as a valid genus (Wisner 1999, McMillan and Wisner 2004, Kuo et al. 2010). Eschmeyer and Fricke (2011) follow Fernholm's advice on this and place all Paramyxine species within Eptatretus. This results in some duplicate names: E. wisneri McMillan 1999 and E. wisneri (Kuo, Huang & Mok 1994) (formerly Paramyxine wisneri Kuo, Huang & Mok 1994); and E. fernholmi McMillan & Wisner, 2004 and E. fernholmi (Kuo, Huang & Mok, 1994) (formerly Paramyxine fernholmi Kuo, Huang & Mok, 1994). To resolve this issue, both E. wisneri McMillan 1999 and E. fernholmi McMillan & Wisner, 2004, as the more recent descriptions, need to be renamed.

The current IUCN Red List retains the genus Paramyxine until the above taxonomic work has been completed.

Fernholm treats the genus Paramyxine Dean, 1908 as a synonym of Eptatretus Cloquet 1819 (Fernholm 1998, Fernholm and Quattrini 2008), while other authors treat Paramyxine as a valid genus (Wisner 1999, McMillan and Wisner 2004, Kuo et al. 2010). Eschmeyer and Fricke (2011) follow Fernholm's advice on this and place all Paramyxine species within Eptatretus. This results in some duplicate names: E. wisneri McMillan 1999 and E. wisneri (Kuo, Huang & Mok 1994) (formerly Paramyxine wisneri Kuo, Huang & Mok 1994); and E. fernholmi McMillan & Wisner, 2004 and E. fernholmi (Kuo, Huang & Mok, 1994) (formerly Paramyxine fernholmi Kuo, Huang & Mok, 1994). To resolve this issue, both E. wisneri McMillan 1999 and E. fernholmi McMillan & Wisner, 2004, as the more recent descriptions, need to be renamed.

The current IUCN Red List retains the genus Paramyxine until the above taxonomic work has been completed.

The number of gill pouches in the original description of P. nelsoni was reported as four, based on the holotype, a small specimen with only four gill apertures. When latter dissected, it was found to have five gill pouches. Kuo and Mok (1999) redescribed the species based on 309 specimens, of which most of them had five and just nine had four gill apertures and/or pouches.

Fernholm treats the genus Paramyxine Dean, 1908 as a synonym of Eptatretus Cloquet 1819 (Fernholm 1998, Fernholm and Quattrini 2008), while other authors treat Paramyxine as a valid genus (Wisner 1999, McMillan and Wisner 2004, Kuo et al. 2010). Eschmeyer and Fricke (2011) follow Fernholm's advice on this and place all Paramyxine species within Eptatretus. This results in some duplicate names: E. wisneri McMillan 1999 and E. wisneri (Kuo, Huang & Mok 1994) (formerly Paramyxine wisneri Kuo, Huang & Mok 1994); and E. fernholmi McMillan & Wisner, 2004 and E. fernholmi (Kuo, Huang & Mok, 1994) (formerly Paramyxine fernholmi Kuo, Huang & Mok, 1994). To resolve this issue, both E. wisneri McMillan 1999 and E. fernholmi McMillan & Wisner, 2004, as the more recent descriptions, need to be renamed.

The current IUCN Red List retains the genus Paramyxine until the above taxonomic work has been completed.
The IUCN SSC Grouper and Wrasse Red List Authority states that Pseudanthias regalis should be Anthias regalis.

The 1996 and 2000 IUCN Red Lists included Hippocampus horai, H. novaehebudorum, H. raji, and H. taeniops. These are now all considered to be synonyms of H. kuda. According to Vincent (1996) and Lourie et al. (1999), there may be as many as ten distinct species that are included under the name Hippocampus kuda. Further research into the literature on this species is needed to determine whether H. kuda is the correct name for populations occurring within the Persian Gulf (T. Munroe pers. comm. 2014).

Specimens from NE Australia are morphologically similar to those from the rest of the Indo-West Pacific (Sara Lourie, unpublished data). Kuiter (2001) however classifies them as H. dahli. Genetic data on BOLD suggest that specimens of putative H. dahli are >5% different from H. trimaculatus and may reflect cryptic speciation. This requires further investigation.

Kuiter (2001) also resurrected H. kampylotrachelos based on a single specimen which, upon examination by SL, was found to be in poor condition, although it did have low fin ray counts for H. trimaculatus.

Eschmeyer (2014) considers H. manadensis to be valid, and H. mannulus to be a synonym of H. comes, however the type descriptions and type specimen (of H. manadensis) clearly ally them with H. trimaculatus . There is a deep genetic division (approx. 2.9% K2P distance) between specimens east and west of Wallace’s line based on 696bp of cyt b mtDNA (Lourie and Vincent, 2004).
This species was originally described as Triathalassothia gloverensis, but was later moved into the genus Vladichthys (Greenfield et al. 2008).

The Lucifuga genus is known as one of the most diverse stygiobiotic fishes to have been described. The taxonomy of Lucifuga species may still be incomplete due to relatively common discoveries of new species. Garcia-Machado et al. (2011) concluded that Lucifuga spp. are genetically divergent, but morphologically indistinguishable and recommends revisiting the taxonomy of the genus. Since the distribution of certain morphological characters among these species are disjointed, they possibly may not be used for classification in the future. A revision of the Lucifuga spp. of Cuba with the description of a new species is currently in preparation by Hernández et al. (Hernández, D., Casane, D., García, A., Chevalier-Monteagudo, P., Møller, P. R. and García-Machado, E.)

Knudsen and Clements (2013) recently revised the family Kyphosidae. They determined that microcanthids, oplegnathids, kuhliids and terapontids are more closely related to Kyphosus than is Girella. Knudsen and Clements (2013) concluded that Girella, Scorpis, and Kyphosus should not be included within the same family and instead, be separated as individual families.

Girella stuebeli was originally described by Troschel (1866) as a different species from Girella zonata, however, the ontogenetic or intraspecific variations are also shown in several species of Girella. Also, there are no substantial morphological character differences recognized. Thus, Girella stuebeli is regarded as a junior synonym of Girella zonata.

Aetobatus ocellatus (Kuhl, 1823) was previously considered to be an Indo-West and Central Pacific form of the wider ranging Aetobatus narinari (Euphrasen, 1790). Comparative analysis of the morphology, molecular and parasite diversity has resulted in the redescription of A. ocellatus from tropical and warm-temperate waters of the Indian Ocean and West-Central Pacific Ocean with A. narinari being restricted to the Atlantic Ocean (Richards et al. 2009, White et al. 2010). Molecular analyses suggest greater levels of speciation within the Aetobatus genus, with distinguishable groups in the Western Indian Ocean and Northwest Pacific (Schluessel et al. 2010, White et al. 2010). Samples from Qatar cluster separately -- designated as A. cf. ocellatus 2 (D. Ebert pers. comm. 2017). This requires further examination to delineate species boundaries.
This species was originally named Serranus fuscus by Lowe (1836), and was previously confused with Mycteroperca rubra, which occurs only along mainland West Africa and the Mediterranean Sea.
Some authors recognize a second species in the southern portion of the range, T. capensis (Smith-Vaniz pers. comm. 2014).
Craig and Hastings (2007) changed the generic name from Epinephelus to Hyporthodus and Smith and Craig (2007) changed the family name to Epinephelidae.
The genus Thunnus is divisible into two subgenera, Thunnus and Neothunnus, but the Bigeye Tuna does not neatly fit in either subgenus (Collette and Graves 2019).
Craig and Hastings (2007) changed the generic name of this species to Hyporthodus, and Smith and Craig (2007) changed the family name to Epinephelidae.
This species is frequently confused with Coryphopterus personatus; C. hyalinus and C. personatus are genetically distinct (Baldwin et al. 2009).

Medusablennius chani was first described in 1966 by V.G. Springer. This species has been assigned to the family Blenniidae but further research is needed to resolve the variability within the blennioid families.
This species was formerly considered a subspecies of Dactyloscopus pectoralis (Hastings and Springer 2009).

Raja maderensis, or a very similar species, is found in the Azores. The taxonomy and relationship of skates on these islands should be assessed. This species is now thought to be distinct from similar specimens from the Canary Islands and West Africa (Ebert and Stehmann 2013).

The wide geographic range of H. histrix (from east Africa to Japan) warrants further investigation, as Song and Mabuchi (2014) suggest that the genetic distance between Indian and Pacific populations is 6.6–6.7% (CO1) and this is also suggested by BOLD (2016) which indicates a 6.13% distinction between specimens from Mozambique/India versus Vietnam/Japan (648bp CO1). This high degree of divergence indicates the presence of at least one cryptic species across the range. There are no genetic data currently available for H. jayakari, which is morphologically very similar to but replaces H. histrix in the Red Sea and Arabian Gulf (Lourie et al. 2016).

The 1996 and 2000 IUCN Red Lists included Hippocampus aimei; this is now considered a synonym of H. barbouri and H. spinosissimus. More recently, Lourie et al. (2016) placed H. alatus (which was listed as Data Deficient in previous versions of the IUCN Red List) into synonymy with H. spinosissimus.

This species is commonly confused with H. histrix.

From Lourie et al. (2016):
The type specimens of H. spinosissimus are surprisingly small, yet they are males with fully developed pouches. They also have clear nose spines, double cheek spines, and all body spines are approximately equally developed. A third specimen labelled as ‘type’ (ZMA 114.473) had single cheek spines. Lourie et al. (1999) used this name to refer to spiny seahorses from across Southeast Asia, even though the latter frequently lacked a nose spine. No genetic data are available from the type specimens. Morphological and genetic data do not support the distinctness of H. queenslandicus nor H. semispinosus from what is understood as H. spinosissimus by Lourie et al.(1999) (Teske et al. 2007; BOLD 2016; see also Zhang et al. 2014). Admittedly there exists variation in spine development and colour pattern among H. spinosissimus specimens and genetic data indicate that haplotype diversity is high, with three major lineages, two of which are broadly sympatric and one that is restricted to the central Philippines (Lourie et al. 2005). However, the genetic divergence among specimens of H. spinosissimus examined from Australia, Malaysia and the Philippines is only 0.82% (648bp, CO1) (BOLD 2016), and the average cytochrome b sequence divergence among 172 specimens from 29 populations is only 1.3% (Lourie et al. 2005). At present we suggest that the variation represents polymorphism within a single species, rather than different species, however further investigation is warranted. Kuiter (2009) and Allen and Erdmann (2012) identify spiny Southeast Asian seahorses variously as H. arnei, H. alatus, H. moluccensis, and H. polytaenia. The illustration of H. polytaenia (Bleeker, 1893) does show markings and moderately developed spines that are reminiscent of H. spinosissimus, however the type specimens conform to H. kuda (SL pers. obs.). Hippocampus alatus is tentatively synonymised here on the basis of morphological similarity, pending further work (especially genetics).

Both Hippocampus mohnikei and H. japonicus were described from Japan and examination of their type specimens shows them to be the same species (Lourie et al. 2016 - Appendix J). Specimens from elsewhere in the Indo-Pacific morphologically conform to H. mohnikei, and differ genetically (e.g. Japanese and Vietnamese specimens differ by an average of 2.25%—648 bp, CO1, BOLD 2016), indicating that there is the possibility of cryptic species within what we know as H. mohnikei.

The type specimen was sent from Algiers, Algeria by Guichenot who reported this species occurred, albeit ‘very rarely’, in Béjaïa (formerly Bougie) (Guichenot 1850). No other specimens have been found from Algeria since this time, and we restrict the current distribution of Hippocampus algiricus to West Africa. H. algiricus is very closely related to the H. kuda-complex (Teske et al. 2005) and is only 1.3% divergent from H. reidi (Silveira et al. 2014; Casey et al. 2004; Teske et al. 2004; BOLD 2016), but is here retained as a valid separate species due to the geographic distance between the West African and Brazilian coasts. Further research is needed to determine the level of connectivity and gene exchange between the two populations.
This species was likely misidentified as Hippocampus erectus prior to its description in 2004.

The genus Horadandia was monotypic until the description of a subspecies, H. atukorali brittani, by Rema Devi & Menon (1992). This subspecies has since been treated uncritically as a synonym of H. atukorali (eg: Rema Devi 1996: 304; Menon 1999: 49). However, Batuwita et al. (2013) distinguished H. atukorali from H. brittani, resulting in two separate species.
This species has been misidentified as Pseudocaranx dentex in the past (Dyer and Westneat 2010).
Aetomylaeus caerulofasciatus has recently been described as distinct from the wider-ranging Indo-West Pacific A. nichofii (White et al. 2015).

Carcharhinus sealei is part of the Carcharhinus seali-dussumieri group that has been revealed to consist of five species: C. dussumieri and C. sealei have recently been re-described, C. coatesi and C. tjutjot have been resurrected as valid species, and a new species, C. humani has been described (White 2012, White and Weigmann 2014).
A taxonomic review of this group is required to properly identify the species of this genus.
Glyphis garricki is sympatric with G. glyphis in northern Australian and southern New Papua Guinea, but the two are separable externally by colouration (Compagno et al. 2008).
Glyphis glyphis is sympatric with G. garricki in northern Australian and southern New Papua Guinea but the two are separable externally by colouration (Compagno et al. 2008).

The Leopard Whipray (Himantura leoparda) is a recently described (2008) species closely related and similar in shape and dorsal disc pattern to the Reticulate Whipray (H. uarnak) and Honeycomb Whipray (H. undulata). These three species are in the ‘uarnak’ species-complex, a subgroup of mainly reticulated, ocellated or spotted whiprays. The Leopard Whipray can be distinguished by its unique arrangement of midscapular denticles and the leopard-like markings on the dorsal surface of adults and large specimens. Juveniles of the three species are born at different sizes and vary slightly in colour patterns and denticle shapes (Manjaji-Matsumoto and Last 2008, Last and Stevens 2009). Taxonomic work is currently ongoing to more clearly define the sister species relationships (P. Last pers. comm. 2010).

Previously, this species has been misidentified as Dasyatis uarnak: Wallace 1967; Himantura fava: Compagno and Roberts 1982; Himantura sp. 1: Gloerfelt-Tarp and Kailola 1984; Himantura uarnak: Compagno 1986, Compagno et al. 1989; and Himantura undulata: Last and Stevens 1994, Last and Compagno 1999, White et al. 2006.

The previously monotypic genus Manta was re-evaluated in 2009 with two species identified, Reef Manta Ray (Manta alfredi) and Giant Manta Ray (Manta birostris) (Marshall et al. 2009). Genetic evidence supported the separation (Kashiwagi et al. 2012). Both species have broad global distributions and are sympatric in some locations and allopatric in others (Kashiwagi et al. 2011, Lawson et al. 2017). A third species of manta ray has also been proposed (Marshall et al. 2009) with increasing genetic support (Hinojosa-Alvarez et al. 2016, Kashiwagi et al. 2017, Hosegood et al. 2018). Genetic evidence has also resulted in the genus Manta being subsumed within the genus Mobula (Poortvliet et al. 2015, White et al. 2018)

Due to the recent taxonomic changes, both present day and historical reports can often be unclear and without adequate descriptions, photographs or geographic locations, it can be difficult to conclusively attribute fisheries data to a single species. Care should be taken when using reports or accounts of the Reef Manta Ray. Melanistic (black) and leucistic (white) colour morphs occur in all species of manta ray (Marshall et al. 2009). Variant colour morphs often contribute an added degree of confusion when attempting to visually discriminate between species of manta rays in the field or in photographs, especially when close examination is not possible. It should be noted that these colour morphs could be a source of error, resulting in mis-identifications in past or future studies or surveys of distribution.
Scymnodon plunketi may be a junior synonym of Scymnodon macracanthus (Regan 1906) (White et al. 2015). Taxonomic clarification is required.
Molecular evidence supports the idea that Rhizoprionodon acutus is a complex of (at least) four species that needs further taxonomic investigation (Naylor et al. 2012).

Squalus montalbani was previously considered a likely junior synonym of S. mitsukurii but was resurrected as a valid species by Last et al. (2007). Referred to as Squalus sp. 1 in White et al. (2006a).
Formerly, U. asperrimus was the only species within Urogymmus. Last et al. (2016) added five more species to the genus.
Appears to hybridize with the Banded Stingaree (Urolophus cruciatis) at the southern end of its range. Further information is required to assess the validity of this species (Last et al. 2016).

Carcharhinus tjutjot is part of the Carcharhinus seali-dussumieri group that has been revealed to consist of five species: C. dussumieri and C. sealei have recently been re-described, C. coatesi and C. tjutjot have been resurrected as valid species, and a new species, C. humani has been described (White 2012, White and Weigmann 2014).

The genus Hypanus formerly was a junior synonym of Dasyatis (Kottelat 2013); it was resurrected by Last et al. (2016) in their revision of the family Dasyatidae.

The nomenclature of this species is often confused, occasionally resulting in the listing of brevis and dipterurus as separate species. Both Jordan and Gilbert and Garman published descriptions of this species in the same year, 1880. However, Jordan and Gilbert published their account of specimens from San Diego in May 1880, while Garman published his description in October of that year. Garman (1913) subsequently overlooked these facts and inappropriately synonymized dipterurus with brevis. However, Jordan and Gilbert's description has precedence.
Previously this species was considered a synonym of Ophioblennius steindachneri (Hastings and Springer 2009).
Based on molecular phylogenetic analysis, Craig and Hastings (2007) consider Epinephelus albomarginatus to be a member of the genus Mycteroperca.
Based on molecular phylogenetic analysis, Craig and Hastings (2007) consider the species Epinephelus marginatus to be a member of genus Mycteroperca.
A recent publication changed the generic name of this species to Hyporthodus (Craig and Hastings 2007) and a change of family name to Epinephelidae (Smith and Craig 2007).
Epinephelus bruneus was recently split into two species, the other being a former synonym of E. bruneus: E. moara (Liu et al. 2013).

The species was first described by Risso (1810) as Squalus ferox from the type locality at Nice and most early records were from the Mediterranean and eastern North Atlantic. Whitley (1950) described O. herbsti from southeastern Australia, differentiating it from O. ferox mainly on differences in dental formulae, and the absence of pigment spots. Garrick's (1974) account of two specimens from New Zealand cast doubt on any differences in dentition between the species but retained O. herbsti for the plain-coloured Odontaspis.

However, Compagno (1984) reviewed the two species and considered that O. herbsti was a junior synonym of O. ferox, noting (as did Robins et al. 1980) that the presence or absence of spots was highly variable, much as with Carcharias taurus. The existence of spotted specimens outside the Mediterranean Sea, including from California (Seigel and Compagno 1986), is supported by in-situ observations made off Lebanon, New Zealand and Malpelo Island (Columbia), where specimens exhibit considerable variability in the presence, density and size of spots. There may be some regionalised trends controlling the intensity of such pigmentation. In the absence of any further evidence to support the validity of an O. ferox/O. herbsti dichotomy, recognition of the single Odontaspis ferox of Risso, as previously argued by Compagno (1984, 2001), remains valid.
This species was previously considered to be conspecific with Aetobatus flagellum, but the species have since been shown to differ genetically and morphologically (White et al. 2013).

Bathytoshia formerly was a junior synonym of Dasyatis, but it is now recognised as a valid genus (Last et al. 2016a); hence Dasyatis (Bathytoshia) lata is now Bathytoshia lata. Molecular data (G. Naylor pers. comm. 1 November 2012) provide evidence that Bathytoshia (as Dasyatis) lata, D. thetidis Ogilby, 1899, D. ushiei (Jordan & Hubbs, 1925), and eastern Atlantic stingrays identified as D. centroura (e.g. McEachran and Capapé 1984), are populations of D. lata (Last et al. 2016a). The species was originally described by Garman (1880) from Hawaii and also confirmed by Fowler (1941). Teng (1962) reported this species from Taiwan (1962) although the record from Taiwan may be a different species.

Last et al. (2016a) revised the family Dasyatidae, erecting the morphologically conservative genus Telatrygon and moving zugei across to this new genus. Telatrygon crozieri (Blyth, 1860) from the northern Indian Ocean is considered distinct from T. zugei (which occurs in the western Pacific).
The genus Hemitrygon formerly was a junior synonym of Dasyatis; it was resurrected by Last et al. (2016a) in their revision of the family Dasyatidae.

Last et al. (2016a) placed Dasyatis colarensis, D. garouaensis, D. geijskesi, D. margarita, D. margaritella, and Urogymnus ukpan within their newly described genus Fontitrygon. Records of Dasyatis (=Fontitrygon) margarita have included misidentified specimens of the smaller sympatric species, F. margaritella.

Himantura heterurus has been placed within the newly described genus Brevitrygon (Last et al. 2016a). Brevitrygon heterura is the correct name of a common western Pacific species, misidentified as Himantura (=Brevitrygon) walga; B. walga is confined to the Indian Ocean (Last et al. 2016a).

Last et al. (2016) described the genus Pateobatis, consisting of five medium-size to very large, marine whiprays previously placed in Himantura (including fai).

This species is frequently misidentified as Himantura (=Pateobatis) jenkinsii.

This species was confused with H. buergeri until Springer and D'Aubrey (1972) found it to be a different species (Compagno 1984). Previously considered to occur in the Philippines, Viet Nam and northwestern Australia but two new species recently described from Indonesia/Philippines and northwestern Australia have resulted in a more restricted range for this species (White et al. 2007). The Viet Nam populations need to be examined further as it is unsure which Halaelurus species they are (W. White pers. obs).

Himantura imbricata has been placed within the newly described genus Brevitrygon (Last et al. 2016a). Brevitrygon imbricata is very similar to B. walga (it is often confused with B. walga), particularly in general disc shape, however their geographical distributions appear limited and almost non-overlapping (P. Last pers. obs). The former is apparently found only in the Indian Ocean, the latter in the South China Sea. Two forms of B. imbricata are recognized, based on the morphology of the tail.

Several papers provide genetic evidence that Lutjanus purpureus, Caribbean Red Snapper, can be considered a synonym of L. campechanus (Gomes et al. 2008, Gomes et al. 2012). All assessors and reviewers agreed that L. campechanus and L. purpureus should be treated according to the many functional differences between the North American and Brazil populations and their massive and distinct biological and management literatures. {need to update this with info from Pedraza-Marron et al 2019 revision of campechanus and purpureus - C. Linardich April 2019}

authority: Barbosa du Bocage & de Brito Capello, 1864

taxonomicNotes: This species belongs to the small, recently designated Telagtrygon genus that consists of four species in the tropical Indo-Pacific (Last et al. 2016a).

Phylogenetic reconstruction has identified the Red Sea taxon Plectropomus pessuliferus marisrubri as a distinct species and sister species to P. laevis with a geographic distribution restricted to the Red Sea.
This species has previously been confused with Gobiodon albolineatus, especially in the Indian Ocean (Winterbottom and Emery 1986).

Note that the type locality reported in Compagno (1984) (Stanley, Falkland Islands) is in error and is correctly Challenger Station 311 (52°45.5'S, 73°46'W), which is in the northwestern Strait of Magellan in the Southeast Pacific (coordinates reported by L.J.V. Compagno in a draft manuscript (unpublished), calculated from Günther's station list in the Challenger Reports; Günther 1887).

Last et al. (2016a) revised the genus Rhinobatos, transferring glaucostigma, horkelii, lentiginosus, leucorhynchus, percellens, planiceps, prahli, and productus to the new genus Pseudobatos.

In Chile, a second rhinobatid species is known from just a dried head: Tarsistes philippi Jordan, 1918. The taxonomic situation of this species is not clear.

A species of Amblyraja has been taken around South Georgia Island which appears not to be A. georgiana, but may be either A. frerichsi or A. robertsi (Mike Endicott via M. Stehmann pers. comm. 2004). The occurrence of this species in the Falklands Islands (Malvinas) is uncertain. Since the inception of the longline fishery around the islands in 1994, this species has been captured in the Falklands as the primary skate by-catch, and recorded as A. cf. georgiana (J. Pompert unpubl. data 2020).

Genetic differences have been detected between Taiwanese and Japanese specimens of Urolophus aurantiacus but there are no major morphological or meristic differences and further work is needed to determine if this is a consistent difference (Ebert et al. 2013, Last et al. 2016).
Myliobatis chilensis is easily differentiated from the sympatric M. peruvianus by colour and rostral fin form.
Myliobatis peruanus was a misspelling of this species. This species is easily differentiated from the sympatric M. chilensis by colour and rostral fin form.

Last et al. (2016a) revised the family Dasyatidae, erecting the genus Telatrygon. Telatrygon acutirostra resembles other species of Telatrygon in disc shape and was previously confused with T. zugei but is distinguishable by a longer snout and tail, smaller eyes, and less well developed dorsal tail fold (Last et al. 2016a). Phylogenetic and whole genome analyses indicate that T. acutirostra does not cluster with other species of Telatrygon, hence its placement in the group is provisional pending more detailed anatomical studies (Last et al. 2016a).
The genus Hemitrygon formerly was a junior synonym of Dasyatis; it was resurrected by Last et al. (2016a) in their revision of the family Dasyatidae.
The genus Hypanus formerly was a junior synonym of Dasyatis (Kottelat, 2013); it was resurrected by Last et al. (2016) in their revision of the family Dasyatidae.
Last et al. (2016) revised the genus Rhinobatos, elevating the former subgenus Acroteriobatus to generic status. This species is commonly misidentified as A. blochii.
Last et al. (2016) revised the genus Rhinobatos, transferring glaucostigma, horkelii, lentiginosus, leucorhynchus, percellens, planiceps, prahli, and productus to the new genus Pseudobatos.
Yano et al. (2004) confirm that sleeper sharks found in the South Atlantic Ocean and Southern Ocean are a separate species, Somniosus antarcticus Whitley, 1939.

Compagno (1999, 2005) reallocated this species from Bathyraja to the genus Rhinoraja but the validity of this move remains unconfirmed. Both are currently in use, but Rhinoraja is now accepted as Bathyraja (Last et al. 2016, Ebert 2016).
Last et al. (2016a) revised the genus Rhinobatos, transferring glaucostigma, horkelii, lentiginosus, leucorhynchus, percellens, planiceps, prahli, and productus to the new genus Pseudobatos.
This species is sometimes called the Spotted Electric Ray, which has resulted in confusion between this species and the Blackspotted Torpedo Ray (Torpedo foscomaculata) (Last et al. 2016).
Moved from Zameus Jordan & Fowler 1903 into Scymnodon Barboza du Bocage & de Brito Capello 1864 by White et al. (2015).

Morphologically similar to some members of the ‘megalops-cubensis group’ but distinguished from those species by the presence of a dark caudal bar. Differs from all other Squalus species in having an unusually low number of precaudal vertebrae (White et al. 2007).

The abundance and geographic range of this species may have been previously overestimated because of confusion between two species (D. tortonesei and D. pastinaca). It is likely that a distinct Dasyatis species lives in the Mediterranean Sea, but with nomenclature issues that are under investigation (Serena 2005, Last et al. 2016).
Last et al. (2016) revised the genus Rhinobatos, transferring glaucostigma, horkelii, lentiginosus, leucorhynchus, percellens, planiceps, prahli, and productus to the new genus Pseudobatos.
This species is possibly sometimes confused with the smaller Smallspotted Catshark (Scyliorhinus canicula).
The distribution of the two other Mustelus species (M. asterias and M. mustelus) overlap with this species and misidentification is probably common.
Previously included a junior synonym, the Maculate Panray (Zanobatus maculatus), which is now a separate species (Last et al. 2016).
This species is very similar to Narcine maculata but can be distinguished by dorsal coloration and the nostril and mouth proportions (Last et al. 2016)
McEachran and Dunne (1998) moved this species from genus Raja to Amblyraja.
Sympatric with the Chinese Numbfish (Narcine lingula) and distinguished by the oronasal region morphology (Last et al. 2016).
The genus Hemitrygon formerly was a junior synonym of Dasyatis; it was resurrected by Last et al. (2016a) in their revision of the family Dasyatidae.

Okamejei kenojei has various morphotypes, which previously lead to some taxonomic confusion. Ishihara (1987, 1990) synonymised Raja atriventralis, R. fusca, R. japonica, R. katsukii, R. kenojei, R. porosa, and R. tobae with (Ishihara et al. 2002).

Previously considered a "Natal" form of Haploblepharus edwardsii (Schinz, 1822) by Bass et al. (1975) and subsequent authors, H. kistnasamyi has a colour pattern that superficially resembles, although is distinct from, that of H. edwardsii, and also differs in morphological features (Human and Compagno 2006). DNA Barcoding confirms that H. kistnasamyi is distinct from H. edwardsii and other Haploblepharus species (K. Geldhill, unpubl. data, 2018).
This species has previously been confused with Okamejei kenojei (Ishihara et al. 2009).
The genus Hemitrygon formerly was a junior synonym of Dasyatis; it was resurrected by Last et al. (2016a) in their revision of the family Dasyatidae.

Recently, molecular data confirmed that the single, widespread Indo–Pacific species, Pastinachus sephen consists of two species, the widespread P. ater and a more restricted P. sephen (Last et al. 2016a).

While there are reported subpopulations of Squalus acanthias (Linnaeus, 1758) elsewhere in the world, the North Pacific subpopulation is now considered a separate species, Squalus suckleyi (Girard, 1854) (see Ebert et al. 2010). Further taxonomic studies on this genus are required, including in relation to Mediterranean and Black Sea subpopulations. In Europe, three subpopulations are inferred to occur.
This species is often misidentified with congenerics.

There is uncertainty about this species' geographical distribution, and taxonomic studies should be undertaken to confirm whether populations from Sundaic southeast Asia are conspecific with those from mainland southeast Asia. Currently, no evidence is available to support this species distribution outside of northwestern Borneo and it is considered that the existing records outside that region are erroneous and likely refer to Tenualosa ilisha or T. macrura (D. Milton pers. com. 2011). Therefore, for the purposes of the assessment, the distribution of Tenualosa toli is restricted to Sarawak, Malaysia.

The Shorttail Yellownose Skate (Dipturus brevicaudatus) was split out from the former species concept of Zearaja chilensis (Gabbanelli et al. 2018). Concha et al. (2019) re-described Zearaja chilensis as Dipturus chilensis and subsumed the genus Zearaja Whitley 1939 as a junior synonym of Dipturus Rafinesque 1810.
In 2009, Craig et al. confirmed that the Pacific “subpopulations” of Epinephelus itajara as a distinct species: E. quinquefasciatus (Craig et al. 2009).
This species is part of the Eviota nigriventris complex (Greenfield and Tornabene 2014), and is closely related to E. raja (Allen et al. 2013).
This species was recently separated from Pogonias cromis (Azpelicueta et al. 2019).
This is a newly described species that was previously referred to as Platyrhina sinensis (Iwatsuki et al. 2011).
This is a newly described species that was previously referred to as Platyrhina sinensis (Iwatsuki et al. 2011).

This species has been confused with the Kwangtung Skate (Dipturus kwangtunensis) that occurs further south; the Polkadot Skate has a shorter snout and more symmetrical pattern on blotches on the dorsal surface (Last et al. 2016).

There was some uncertainty that this species should be known as Gobionellus atripinnis, however, it is currently considered to be valid as Ctenogobius claytonii. Gobionellus atripinnis is considered a junior synonym (L. Tornabene and F. Pezold pers. comm. 2015).

Microsatellite markers demonstrated within- and among-population genetic variability. Over most of its range, genetic differentiation was subtle. Geographically isolated and peripheral populations were much more distinct. Populations from Florida, the Pacific of Panama, Gulf of Guinea, and Costa Rica, were genetically differentiated (Ward et al. 2008). It is unknown to what extent larval dispersal versus adult migrations contribute to this differentiation (Adams pers. comm. 2011).
Previously confused with Boeseman's Skate (Okamejei boesemani) which shares similar colouration to the Borneo Sand Skate (O. cairae) but differs in morphology (Last et al. 2010a).

The species is distinguished from its regional congeners, the Bengal Guitarfish (Rhinobatos annandalei) and Smoothback Guitarfish (R. lionatus) by colour, morphology, and meristic characters (Last et al. 2019).

Anguilla borneensis is the only plain-coloured, longfinned eel found in Indonesia. It typically has 103–108 vertebrae (Watanabe et al. 2014) and grows to a maximum length of 80 cm TL. It has been suggested that this species and A. mossambica could be basal species of the genus (Aoyama et al. 2001, Minegishi et al. 2005, Fahmi 2015).

Anguilla luzonensis is morphologically similar to other anguillids A. celebesensis and A. interioris, and so molecular techniques would be required to accurately distinguish this species (Minegishi et al. 2009, Leander et al. 2012). Similar to A. celebesensis, this anguillid eel is characterised by mottled colouration with broad maxillary bands of teeth. The two species cannot be distinguished by morphological differences in predorsal, preanal and trunk length or in number of vertebrae because of their overlapping range. Anguilla luzonensis is reported to have 103–106 vertebrae. It has a predorsal-fin length of 28.6–33.1% of TL; preanal length 39.6–44.8% of TL; preanal length without head length (trunk length) 26.4–31.3% of TL; distance between the verticals through the anus and origin of the dorsal fin 9.3–13.9% of TL; LG 35.5–46.9% of HL; TV 103–107; and AV 40–42. The body is elongate. Body colour when fresh is mottled with yellow, olive green, and dark brown or black. HL is 10.8-15.1% of TL, predorsal length without head length is 15.5–19.7% of TL. A. luzonensis has 61–66 caudal vertebrae (Watanabe et al. 2009).
This is a recently described species. It was originally placed in the genus Arius. A revised (unified) nomenclature for Ariidae is currently underway (R. Betancur pers. comm. 2014).

Last et al. (2016) described the genus Pateobatis, consisting of five medium-size to very large, marine whiprays previously placed in Himantura (including jenkinsii).

This species has probably been misidentified as Himantura (=Pateobatis) fai in the literature (W. White pers. obs). More specimens of both this species and of H. draco from South Africa need to be examined to resolve the taxonomic status of this species. Presently, H. draco is considered a synonym of P. jenkinsii. The South African species had dark spots along the posterior margin of the disc, but this form has also been reported from the Arafura Sea and off Sumatra in Indonesia. It is possible that these may in fact be colour forms of the same species. Examples of specimens with dark spots along the posterior margin of the disc are from the Arafura Sea, Sumatra (Last and Stevens 1994, Fahmi pers. obs. 2007), and from western Sri Lanka (Morón et al. 1998, Manjaji 2004), and the Sulu Sea (B.M. Manjaji-Matsumoto pers. obs. 2002).
Formerly a monotypic genus (containing only U. asperrimus), Last et al. (2016) added five more species to Urogymmus, including U. granulatus.
This new species was split from Hypanus americanus (Petean et al. 2020)
There is some genetic evidence that suggests there is a cryptic species in the Red Sea (K. Yan Ma pers. comm. 2016).

The species can be distinguished from the similar regional congener, the Shovelnose Guitarfish (Pseudobatos productus) by a narrower disc width and shorter distance between nostril and disc margin (Rutledge et al. 2019).

Hemiscyllium galei was recently described as a separate species by Allen and Erdmann (2008). It was previously confused with the Indonesian Speckled Carpet Shark (H. freycineti), which is apparently restricted to West Papua Province (far western New Guinea), Indonesia. The two species differ primarily in colour pattern, which provides the best means of separating the various members of the genus. Phylogenetic analysis with mitochondrial DNA (ND4) also clearly separates H. galei from other hemiscyllid species including H. freycineti.

Henry’s Epaulette Shark (Hemiscyllium henryi) is most similar to the Epaulette Shark (H. ocellatum) which has previously been thought to exist in Papua New Guinea, but likely is not found there. The latter species is most likely restricted to Australian waters (Allen and Erdmann 2008). Colour pattern features and DNA analysis provide the best means of separation between the two species.

Michael’s Epaulette Shark (Hemiscyllium michaeli) has recently been described as a new species (Allen and Dudgeon 2010). It was previously confused with the Indonesian Speckled Carpet Shark (H. freycineti) (Compagno 2002) which is apparently restricted to West Papua Province (far western New Guinea), Indonesia. The two species differ primarily in colour pattern which provides the best means of separating the various members of the genus. Phylogenetic analysis with mitochondrial DNA (ND4) also clearly separates the two species (Allen and Dudgeon 2010).
Easily confused with the Southern Eagle Ray (Myliobatis goodei) (Last et al. 2016).
Crassinarke dormitor is now included as a synonym of Narke japonica (Compagno and Heemstra 2007, Carvalho et al. 2016).
